doc.field: Hamburg's Social Democrats want Finance Minister Runde to run for mayor. 53-year old Mr Runde got 264 out of 287 votes. He is to be Mr Voscherau's successor (who resigned after his party did not do well at all at the last state elections).
Negotiations on early retirement/part-time work deadlocked

Arbitrator Spoeri, who was trying to sort out things when award-talks in Baden-Wuerttemberg's metal-industry hit a stalemate over plans for early retirement/part-time work, agreed that they in fact seemed to have got nowhere. And aggro and stress had got worse, too. A spokes-person for the union agreed that they effectively were stuck. The main bone of contention was and is if the agreement would get written into the awards, making it compulsory for all employers concerned.
New Chancellor's Office to be built in Berlin

Chancellor Kohl laid the first brick for his new office in Berlin, reassuring everyone that government would shift to Berlin until 1999, as planned. He said that extending the former capital of Berlin was an important task from a national and political viewpoint. His new office will cost approximately 400 million marks.

NATO foreign ministers and their Russian counterpart, Mr Primakov, agreed on closer military co-operation. During the first meeting of the NATO-Russia Council in New York, they also agreed to enhance co-operation for peacekeeping- and relief-missions. All concerned thought the meeting had been a full success, and US Foreign Minister Albright was happy, too. The next meeting will be in December, in Brussels. The decision to have these meetings had been made last summer, when plans had been hatched to extend NATO by granting membership to some eastern countries.
Green light for new organ-transplant law

The Upper House (Bundesrat) gave the green light to a new law on organtransplants. Now the extended consent-system will prevail, so relatives of the deceased may also have their say as far as organ-transplants were concerned. The house also passed a remit on fighting crime, and asked government to use the law on associations to investigate against the Scientology Organisation.
Meat processor banned from buying and selling imported meat

Meat processor Nordland of Heidenkirchen in Schleswig-Holstein will be banned from trading with imported meat, as State Minister of Agriculture Steenblock confirmed today. The company allegedly had been buying and selling illegally imported British beef.

The Dusseldorf Upper Regional Court sentenced a man from Serbia to life imprisonment for war-crimes he had committed in Bosnia. The 50-year old man was convicted of 11 cases of genocide, 30 murders and unlawful detention. Allegedly he had played a major role in the killing of Muslims in 1992. The court followed the public prosecutor's plea. Defence counsel had claimed that the case was not within the court's jurisdiction, and wanted their client released. The verdict stated that, as the crimes were particularly grave, there would be no question of releasing the offender after 15 years (on parole).
At least four Germans die in Sumatra plane-crash

According to officials all 234 passengers and crew on board a domestic Indonesian airline flight were killed when the plane crashed in Sumatra. The Foreign Ministry said that there were at least four German nationals among the dead. The Garuda Airbus was flying from Djakarta to Medan, in the northern part of Sumatra. So far there was no confirmation that the haze currently blanketing parts of South-East Asia was to blame
Parachute-jumper hits four killing them when parachute does not open

When a parachute-jumper fell to his death he hit some people gathered outside Halle/Saale's soccer stadium killing four of them. He should have landed inside the stadium to kick off an Upper League soccer game, but his parachute failed.
